profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born near Clinton, Laurens County, S.C., August 13, 1789; pursued an academic course; engaged as a planter; served in the State house of representatives 1816-1819; member of the State senate 1820-1824 and again in 1828; elected as a Nullifier to the Twenty-second through Twenty-fifth Congresses and reelected as a Democrat to the Twenty-sixth Congress (March 4, 1831-March 3, 1841); died near Clinton, S.C., August 1, 1841; interment in Little River Church Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1831, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John King Griffin to Dr. John H. Davis written on December 7, 1831. In the letter, Griffin regarding Davis's subscription to the [United States] Telegraph [a Washington, D.C., newspaper], praising political beliefs espoused by the editor [Duff Green (1791-1875)], which were compatable with Griffin's, expressing his approval that Davis and King's other constituents were subscribing to the Telegraph, "the proper Source" for reliable coverage regarding the proceedings of Congress. Griffin notes concerns re duties and the tariff, speculation re the ratio for representation, and comments on three rival factions in Congress - the "Van Buren-Jackson" men, the "Calhoun-Jackson" men, and "the Clayites, "--Reflected in election of the Speaker of the House, and reporting that J[ohn] C. Calhoun had not yet arrived due to severe weather.
